title: 108_hr1997
content: The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as "Laci and Conner's Law," amends Title 18 of the United States Code to include a new chapter, "Protection of Unborn Children," which outlines measures for the protection of unborn children. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as "Laci and Conner's Law," establishes a separate offense for causing harm to a child in utero due to violating certain laws. The punishment for this offense is similar to the punishment for causing harm to the unborn child's mother under Federal law. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 creates a separate offense for causing harm to an unborn child, with punishment similar to harming the mother under Federal law. Proof of knowledge or intent regarding the pregnancy is not required for this offense. If the person intentionally kills or attempts to kill the unborn child, different consequences apply. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes a separate offense for harming an unborn child, with penalties similar to harming the mother under Federal law. Knowledge or intent regarding the pregnancy is not necessary for this offense. If the person intentionally kills or attempts to kill the unborn child, different consequences apply. The death penalty is not applicable for this offense. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes penalties for harming an unborn child, with separate consequences for intentionally killing or attempting to kill the unborn child. The death penalty is not applicable for this offense. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 lists numerous sections of various acts that are not to be construed as permitting prosecution. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 specifies sections of different acts that do not allow prosecution for certain conduct related to abortion or medical treatment of pregnant women or unborn children. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 prohibits prosecution for conduct related to abortion with consent, medical treatment of pregnant women or unborn children, or a woman with respect to her unborn child. It defines 'unborn child' as a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development in the womb. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 defines 'unborn child' as a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development in the womb. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 defines 'unborn child' as a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development in the womb. Section 3 of the Military Justice System includes protection for unborn children under the Uniform Code of Military Justice. Any person subject to the Military Justice System who causes harm to a child in utero due to violating certain laws will face a separate offense with punishment determined by a court-martial. Proof of harm to the unborn child's mother is not required for this offense. Any person subject to the Military Justice System who causes harm to an unborn child shall be punished as directed by a court-martial, consistent with punishments for similar conduct towards the mother. Proof of knowledge or intent regarding the pregnancy is not required for this offense. If the conduct results in the intentional killing or attempted killing of the unborn child, a different punishment applies. The Military Justice System punishes harm to an unborn child without requiring proof of knowledge or intent regarding the pregnancy. If the conduct results in the intentional killing or attempted killing of the unborn child, a different punishment applies, and the death penalty is not imposed for this offense. The Military Justice System does not impose the death penalty for intentionally killing or attempting to kill a human being, including an unborn child. The specific sections of the law that apply to this offense are outlined in subsection (b) of the statute. The specific sections of the law (articles 918, 919(a), 919(b)(2), 920(a), 922, 924, 926, and 928) do not permit prosecution for conduct related to abortion with consent, medical treatment of the pregnant woman or her unborn child, or any woman with respect to her unborn child. The term 'unborn child' refers to a child in this section. The law allows for consent for medical treatment of a pregnant woman or her unborn child, as well as for any woman with respect to her unborn child. The term 'unborn child' refers to a child in utero, a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development.
